revision.text:
{{Infobox album | name = Back to Titanic | type = [[Soundtrack]] | artist = [[James Horner]] | cover = Backtotitaniccover.jpg | alt = | released = August 25, 1998 | recorded = February 2, 1998 – July 9, 1998 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Soundtrack]] | length = 79:05 | label = [[Sony Music]] | producer = [[James Horner]] | prev_title = [[The Mask of Zorro#Music|The Mask of Zorro]] | prev_year = 1998 | next_title = [[Mighty Joe Young (1998 film)#Music|Mighty Joe Young]] | next_year = 1998 }} {{Album ratings |rev1 = [[Allmusic]] |rev1score = {{Rating|3|5}}<ref>{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r373377|first=Stephen Thomas|last=Erlewine|accessdate=2011-09-02}}</ref> }}<!-- Automatically generated by DASHBot-->
'''''Back to Titanic''''' is the second soundtrack album released for the [[Titanic (1997 film)|film]], which contains a mixture of previously unreleased recordings and newly recorded performances of the songs in the film.
After the success of the [[Titanic: Music from the Motion Picture|first soundtrack]] album, [[James Horner]] created a new suite of music, comprising light and dark sections from the score, which represents the "soul" of his music for the film.
==Album information== In addition, several of the source numbers from the film were included into this second album. From "Nearer My God to Thee" to the raucous [[Pipe (instrument)|pipe]] and [[drum]] rhythms heard in the [[Irish folk music]] played in the lower decks, these selections recreate the most poignant moments in the life and death of the great ship.
"Alexander's Ragtime Band" was played on the deck by [[Wallace Hartley]]'s small orchestra and lifted spirits as the ship settled, lights blazing, into black oblivion. And "Come Josephine, in My Flying Machine", which Jack Dawson briefly sings for Rose DeWitt Bukater and Rose sings when she is waiting to be rescued in the freezing seas. The song was a top hit song the year before the sinking.
==Commercial performance== Although it did not manage to reach the success of its counterpart soundtrack, ''Back to Titanic'' was a big commercial success, especially considering that the film and original soundtrack were released over eight months before it. It debuted at No. 7 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and then the following week reached its peak position at No. 2 with 164,000 copies sold. (It was kept off the top spot by [[Lauryn Hill]]'s ''[[The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill]]'', which sold 265,000 copies that same week.) ''Back to Titanic'' has been certified Platinum in the United States for sales of over 1 million copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS |title=Recording Industry Association of America |publisher=RIAA |date= |accessdate=2011-09-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130225031458/http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS |archivedate=2013-02-25 |df= }}</ref>
It was also certified gold in Japan for 100,000 copies shipped to stores in September 1998.<ref name="RIAJ-nov1998">{{cite journal |title=GOLD ALBUM 他認定作品 1998年9月度 |trans-title=Gold Albums, and other certified works. September 1998 Edition |url=http://www.riaj.or.jp/issue/record/1998/199811.pdf |format=PDF | journal=The Record |type=Bulletin |language=Japanese |location=[[Chūō, Tokyo]] |publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of Japan]] |publication-date=November 10, 1998 |volume=468 |page=9 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140124032014/http://www.riaj.or.jp/issue/record/1998/199811.pdf |archivedate=January 24, 2014 |accessdate=January 24, 2014}}</ref>
In 2012, the album, along with its [[Titanic: Music from the Motion Picture|predecessor]], was re-issued as part of the ''Collector's Anniversary Edition'' set for the [[Titanic (1997 film)#3D conversion|3D re-release]] of the film.
==Track listing== All music composed and conducted by James Horner, except where noted. {{tracklist | extra_column = Artist
| title1 = ''Titanic'' Suite | extra1 = James Horner | length1 = 19:05 | title2 = An Irish Party in Third Class | extra2 = [[Gaelic Storm]] | length2 = 3:48 | title3 = [[Alexander's Ragtime Band]] | extra3 = [[I Salonisti]] | length3 = 2:31 | title4 = The Portrait | extra4 = James Horner | length4 = 4:44 | title5 = Jack Dawson's Luck | extra5 = James Horner | length5 = 5:39 | title6 = A Building Panic | extra6 = James Horner | length6 = 8:09 | title7 = [[Nearer, My God, to Thee|Nearer My God to Thee]]<!--Punctuation is correct, as on the back cover.--> | extra7 = I Salonisti | length7 = 2:51 | title8 = [[Come Josephine in My Flying Machine|Come Josephine, in My Flying Machine]]<!--Punctuation is correct, as on the back cover.--> | extra8 = [[Moya Brennan|Máire Brennan]] | length8 = 3:33 | title9 = Lament | extra9 = James Horner | length9 = 4:37 | title10 = A Shore Never Reached | extra10 = James Horner | length10 = 4:27 | title11 = [[My Heart Will Go On]] | note11 = Dialogue Mix | extra11 = [[Celine Dion]] | length11 = 4:43 | title12 = Nearer My God to Thee<!--Punctuation is correct, as on the back cover.--> | extra12 = [[Eileen Ivers]] | length12 = 2:23 | title13 = Epilogue – The Deep and Timeless Sea<!--Punctuation is correct, as on the back cover.--> | extra13 = James Horner | length13 = 12:38 }}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.backtotitanic.com/}}
[[Category:James Horner albums]] [[Category:1998 soundtracks]] [[Category:Titanic (1997 film)]] [[Category:Sequel albums]]

{{Infobox television |image = |caption = |show_name = Brown Girls |creator = Fatimah Asghar |director = Sam Bailey |writer = Fatimah Asghar |starring = Nabila Hossain
Sonia Denis |theme_music_composer = [[Jamila Woods]] |country = United States |language = English |num_seasons = 1 |num_episodes = 6 |runtime = |list_episodes = |executive_producer = |network = Open TV |first_aired = {{start date|2017|02|15}} |last_aired = |website = }} '''''Brown Girls''''' is an American [[comedy]] [[web series]] created by Fatimah Asghar and Sam Bailey. It follows two friends, Leila and Patricia, who pursue their dreams in Chicago.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/06/hbo-brown-girls-comedy-web-series-1202108531/ |title=HBO Developing ‘Brown Girls’ Comedy Based On Web Series |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |date=June 6, 2017 |accessdate=July 17, 2017}} ==Premise== Two women of color, Leila and Patricia, a queer Pakistani-American writer and an African-American musician, lean on each other to get through the difficulties of their mid-twenties. ==Development and production== Directed by Sam Bailey and written by Fatimah Asghar, the series was inspired by Asghar's 10-year-long friendship with singer [[Jamila Woods]]. Scripting began in the fall of 2015, and Bailey joined the project after a public reading in early 2016. Founder of Open TV Aymar Jean Christian added the project to the web platform's slate. Filming took place in Chicago's [[Lower West Side, Chicago|Pilsen neighborhood]].{{cite web|url=http://www.elle.com/culture/movies-tv/interviews/a43062/brown-girls-fatimah-asghar-sam-bailey-interview/ |title=Watch the Debut Episode of Revolutionary New Web Series Brown Girls |work=[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]] |first=Britt |last=Julious |date=February 15, 2017 |accessdate=July 17, 2017}} ==Reception== The series debuted on [[Elle (magazine)|Elle.com]] in February 2017. It attracted immediate attention from [[HBO]], [[Comedy Central]] and [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]]. HBO put the series into development in June 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2017/07/all-the-brown-girls-on-tv/530184/ |title=All the Brown Girls on TV |work=[[The Atlantic]] |first=Mallika |last=Rao |date=July 9, 2017 |accessdate=July 17, 2017}} The series was nominated for the [[Primetime Emmy Award]] for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Short Form Comedy or Drama Series|Outstanding Short Form Comedy or Drama Series]].{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/awards/nominees-winners/2017/outstanding-short-form-comedy-or-drama-series |title=Nominees/Winners | Television Academy |publisher=[[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]] |date= |accessdate=July 17, 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.browngirlswebseries.com/ Official website] {{Streamy Awards Winners CSS}} [[Category:2017 web series debuts]] [[Category:American web series]] [[Category:Comedy web series]] [[Category:LGBT-related web series]]

{{For|people name Brumm|Brumm (surname)}} [[Image:Brumm.jpg|thumb|right|300px]] [[File:Auto Union tipo D 1938 Brumm ORO R109 (6890769575).jpg|thumb|300px|right|Brumm Auto Union Tipo D from 1938.]] '''Brumm''' is a collectible model company that makes diecast metal automobiles and horse-drawn carriages. It is based in Oltrona di San Mamette, southwest of Lake Como, Italy - about 25 miles northwest of Milan (Johnson 1998, 32–33). Models are almost exclusively produced in 1:43 scale.
==History== Veteran collector and U.S. importer David Sinclair reports that Brumm was started in 1972 by Reno Tattarletti of the family concern that started [[RIO Models]] (other sources say it was a brother-in-law of the Tattarlettis; see Levine 2009; Sinclair 1979, p. 389; Sinclair's 1975 and 1978). Rio Models, in turn, had earlier begat [[Dugu Miniautotoys]] to produce models for the Turin auto museum.
The new company was formed with the help of a couple of associates who had already been making miniature horse-drawn carriages (Force 1992, p. 106). Brumm thus started producing miniature vehicles in Oltrona di San Mamette about seven miles from where RIO was located in Cernobbio. Oddly, neither the RIO nor the Dugu connection is discussed in the company history on the official Brumm website. [[File:Brumm X01 Carro di Cuginot.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Cugnot's 1769 steam tractor from France (Model X01)]] The name Brumm was derived from the Italian for 'Brougham' (Force 1992, 106). As quoted from Brumm's official 1995 catalog, with a silly dark drama partly arising from a sloppy translation of Italian into English – "It was a dark and stormy night...a dense fog screen wound the city of Milan. Nobody dared get out of the house, and in the desert[ed] streets you only heard the squeaking of a black carriage – the Brumm [of] Milan" (Brumm, 1995).
==Carriages and steam== Carriages then (with horses available), made up the first Brumm line. In 1976, the "Old Fire" series followed, and then the Revival series of motorcars. The Old Fire series at first focused on steam fire engines and other fairly well known pre-gas engine vehicles such as Richard Trevithick's 1803 steam carriage. Soon, the line was expanded into a unique set of steam-powered vehicles – something no toy manufacturer had ever done before. This included Cugnot's 1769 steam tractor from France, proposed for pulling military cannon, and later, two fantastical steam cars: one supposedly made by Ferdinand Verbiest in 1681, and another proposed by Newton in 1680 – neither confirmed to have ever been actually constructed. Such novel choices for steam propulsion did not stop with European concoctions; for example Oliver Evans' 'Oruktor Amphibolos' was a steam dredge demonstrated in Philadelphia in 1804 (Sinclair's 1981). [[File:Brumm Fiat 500 America.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Brumm Models Fiat 500 America with cloth top. Note the intricacy of the details, but also untrimmed plastic parts and poor diecast lines.]] The Carriage and Old Fire series were produced in detailed plastic very similar to [[Minialuxe]] of France or some [[Cursor Models]] of Germany. The Revival series of more modern automobiles, however, were produced in zamac – the first of the series being the cute and classic Morgan Sport 3-wheeler with the V-Twin engine hanging off of the front, which no one had ever produced before in miniature.
Another unique model choice was Henry Ford's 1902 model 999 land speed record car (see Force 1992, pp. 107–110 for models produced up to about 1980). This model caused a legal row with Rio, who had produced their own version of the 999. Thus the two sides of the Tattarletti family fought over whose model was first and more authentic. Sinclair reports that Rio won that battle, thus Brumm perhaps has made fewer of the 999 than Rio (Sinclair 1979, p. 389).
Brumm Models were advertised as "not toys and unsuitable for children" – a fact emphasized on the packaging which recommends that models are only suitable for ages ''14 and up''. Most Brumm models, similar to RIO and Dugu, were offered in top up or top down versions and these versions were offered in distinct colors. Unlike RIO, however, Brumm models rarely had opening features which made RIO seem the better value for the price. RIO chassis were better detailed and also, at times, Brumm paint applications could be rather thick.
==Attempting to best RIO== [[File:Fiat 500 B Topolino 1946 and 500 C 1949.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Brumm Fiat Topolino 500 vans. Left is the 500 B from 1946 and a 500 C from 1949. These selections show the company's aim at reproducing closely related models.]] For RIO, diecast cars were once a sideline to a tool and die business. In comparison to RIO, however, Brumm produced a larger range of different models from the 1970s forward. It continues as one of the most prolific European collector oriented diecast firms today, though some of its offerings and approach are similar to [[Vitesse Models|Vitesse]] or [[Eligor Models|Eligor]] which also offer interesting mixes of vintage with newer vehicles. According to a stock sheet from 2003 on the official website, throughout its existence the company had produced over a hundred models consisting of 353 different liveries. By comparison, RIO Models though fewer in number carried a more refined and pristine feel. RIO often surpassed Brumm in creativity, but not in sheer production numbers, Brumm is the leader.
While RIO focused on classic as well as newer production cars, Brumm focused on period racing vehicles (Castellarin 2002). Brumm's later models expanded to 1930s to 1950s race cars, accurately copying the real cars, down to varied numbering, striping, and nationalistic color schemes according to driver or to particular race. Early FIATs, Ferraris, and Alfa Romeos were common, but German and British cars also were in the line-up. For example, the 1938 Mercedes W125 Grand Prix no. 15 model accurately portrayed all kinds of intricate details including tiny rear-view mirror, low profile windscreen, suspension detail, authentic looking wire wheels, brown 'leather' hood strap, and disc brakes. This car raced in the United States and the model even portrays the Nazi flag on the rear of the body. [[File:Fiat 600 Multipla 1956-69 by Brumm.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The Fiat 600 Multipla, very nicely rendered.]] Later, racing Ferraris and Alfa Romeos from the 1970s and 1980s were offered. Examination of company catalogs easily shows that European diecast manufacturers favored the 'patria', so naturally, Italian brands were prevalent in the Brumm line, though British Jaguars, the Vanwall, and Mercedes-Benzes were also represented in miniature. Different liveries were offered for promotional purposes, like Jägermeister racing FIATs, AGIP, Campari rum, or Amaro liqueur vans, or an Olio FIAT 600 multipla. At least some of these offerings Brumm referred to as its "Serie Commerciale". Other nationalistic themes were seen in examples such as the Porsche Speedster with Eva Perón markings.
Starting in 1986, an annual series of limited production models was begun and in 1987 the beginning Revival line was discontinued (though still proudly shown in catalogs a decade later. Brumm 1995; Johnson 1998, 33). Pride in the models produced was evident and the traditional Brumm carriage became the company logo for most packaging. [[File:Ferrari 500 F.2 1952 Brumm ORO R44 (6890768045).jpg|thumb|250px|left|1950 Ferrari 500 F2. Brumm also did a number of race cars in several accurate designs to particular races.]] Continuing the quote from the 1995 Brumm catalog, "Suddenly the indefinite profiles...were lit by blinding lightning and a freezing discharge of thunder awoke the city...a furtive shadow...comes out of the carriage and started narrating the history of automobile thought...a storm of miniature models...the Brumm Tempest." Again, the image is dramatically goofy, but the point is valid – especially in comparison with stepfather RIO, Brumm has been industrious indeed (Castellarin 2002). Brumm even announces models sometimes years before they actually appear (Force 1992, 107).
==Brumm today== Into the new millennium, Brumm continues with most of its traditional models while occasionally producing a new Ferrari, Lotus or Alfa Romeo, but since about 1990 fewer models have been produced – about one new model annually. A new sales angle appeared when semi-promotional models appeared, such as FIAT 500s with names of European political candidates on their sides (and yes, even one with 'Obama'). Also like RIO, models, often racing vehicles, are often sold in lifelike dioramas (see Autostory collection website).
==References== *''The Brumm Tempest''. 1995. Official Brumm company catalog. All color, 60 pp. *Castellarin, Danilo. 2002. ''Li brumm 1972/2002, una storia di modelli''. Collector's Book sponsored by Brumm. *Force, Edward. 1992. ''Classic Miniature Vehicles Made in Italy''. Schiffer Publications. {{ISBN|0-88740-433-2}} *Johnson, Dana. 1998. ''Collector's Guide to Diecast Toys & Scale Models'', second edition. Collector Books, A Division of Schroeder Publishing. *Levine, R. F. 2009. David Sinclair in the Driver's Seat. ''Lake Erie LifeStyle'', web published December 1. [http://www.goerie.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20091201/LEL05/311259869] * Sinclair, David. 1979. Scale 1:43, a Survey for Collectors, in ''Automobile Quarterly'', Vol. 17, No. 4, Pp. 384–399. Princeton, New Jersey: Automobile Quarterly, Inc. in Association with the Princeton Institute for Historic Research. *Sinclair's Auto Miniatures. 1975. Typewritten newsletter and ads describing a variety of products. *Sinclair's Auto Miniatures. 1978. Typewritten newsletter and ads describing Brumm line in detail. *Sinclair's Auto Miniatures. 1981. "The Age of Steam". Color advertising leaflet.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100326205919/http://www.brumm.it/ Official website] [[Category:Die-cast toys]] [[Category:1:43 scale models]] [[Category:Como]] [[Category:Companies based in Lombardy]] [[Category:Toy companies of Italy]] [[Category:Toy brands]] [[Category:Italian brands]] [[Category:Design companies established in 1972]] [[Category:1972 establishments in Italy]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1972]]

revision.text:
'''Cumbia villera''' ({{IPA-es|ˈkumbja βiˈʒeɾa|local}} or {{IPA-es|ˈkumbja βiˈʃeɾa|}}) (roughly translated as ''"[[slum]] cumbia"'', ''"[[ghetto]] cumbia"'' or ''"[[shantytown]] cumbia"'') is a subgenre of [[cumbia]] music originated in the slums of [[Argentina]] and popularized all over [[Latin America]] and the Latin communities abroad.<ref name="rollingstone">[https://www.rollingstone.com.ar/583428 "El ritmo de la villa", Rolling Stone]</ref>
Lyrically, cumbia villera uses the vocabulary of the marginal and lower classes, like the Argentine ''[[lunfardo]]'' and ''lenguaje tumbero'' («gangsta language» or «thug language»), and deals with themes such as the everyday life in the ''[[villas miseria]]'' (slums), poverty and misery, the use of hard drugs, promiscuity and/or prostitution, night outs at ''boliches'' (discos and clubs) that play cumbia and other tropical music genres (such as the emblematic ''Tropitango'' venue in [[General Pacheco|Pacheco]]),<ref name="rollingstone" /> the [[Association football|football]] culture of the [[barra brava]]s, delincuency and clashes with the police and other forms of authority, antipathy towards politicians, authenticity as of being true ''villeros'' (the inhabitants of the ''villas''), among other topics dealt in cumbia villera's lyrics.<ref name="rollingstone" /><ref>[http://archivo.losandes.com.ar/notas/2001/8/5/sociedad-266676.asp "“No me pidas que deje de robar...”", Los Andes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150722071203/http://archivo.losandes.com.ar/notas/2001/8/5/sociedad-266676.asp |date=2015-07-22 }}</ref>
Musically, cumbia villera bases its sound in a heavy use of [[synthesizer]]s, sound effects, keyboard voices, [[keytar]]s, [[electronic drum]]s and other elements from [[electric instrument]]s. The cumbia villera's characteristic sound was born taking influences from [[Colombia]]n and [[Peruvian cumbia|Peruvian]] cumbia, ''cumbia sonidera'' and ''cumbia [[Santa Fe Province|santafesina]]'' in the realm of cumbia, and from [[reggae]], [[ska]], [[Argentine folklore]], and [[electronic music]] in other music genres.<ref name="rollingstone" /> Lastly, the creator of cumbia villera, [[Pablo Lescano]], admitted that his lyrics were influenced by bands from Argentine [[punk rock]] like [[2 Minutos]] and Argentine rock [[rolinga]] like [[Viejas Locas]].<ref name="amarga">[http://www.laopinionsemanario.com.ar/noticia/nunca-vi-una-vecina-tan-amarga-como-vos-29854 "Nunca vi una vecina tan amarga como vos", La Opinión Semanario]</ref><ref>[http://www.lmneuquen.com.ar/noticias/2012/7/7/extranas-relaciones_153926 "Extrañas relaciones", La Mañana Neuquén]</ref> This overview is not definitive, as time went on and the genre evolved, many bands started to explore different sounds, so new fusions were born,<ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com.ar/1276330 "Conocé a Fantasma", Rolling Stone Argentina]</ref> like ''[[cumbia rapera]]'' with [[Bajo Palabra]] (''«[[Parole]]»'') mixing cumbia villera with [[hip hop]], and ''[[tropipunk]]'' with [[Kumbia Queers]] mixing cumbia villera with [[punk rock|punk]].
For its characteristics, cumbia villera has been compared to [[gangsta rap]], [[reggaeton]], [[punk rock]], [[tango]], [[Argentine foklore]], rock [[rolinga]], [[protest song]], [[ragga]]muffin, [[baile funk]], [[outlaw country]], and [[narcocorrido]], among other music genres.<ref name="rollingstone" />
==History==
Cumbia villera was born in the late 1990s, amid an economic and social decline in Argentina.<ref name="rollingstone" /><ref name="ventana">[http://www.clarin.com/zona/cumbia-villera-ventana-procesa-desigualdad_0_653334854.html “La cumbia villera es una gran ventana para ver cómo se procesa la desigualdad”, Clarín]</ref> The introduction of [[neoliberal]] economics in Argentina in the early '90s gave a quick boost to the nation's economy but progressively marginalized large areas of the society, and by the late '90s, Argentina was in a [[1998–2002 Argentine great depression|total and implacable depression]]. Some of the most affected by this crisis were the worker and lower classes, and among them were the inhabitant and dwellers of the ''[[villas miseria]]'' ([[slum]]s or [[shantytown]]s) in [[Buenos Aires]] and its metropolitan area, which favoured [[cumbia]] and other tropical music genres.<ref name="rollingstone" /> However, through the '90s, Argentine cumbia bands such as [[Grupo Sombras]] (''«Group Shadows»'') or [[Grupo Green]] didn't touch social issues and in fact their lyrics were limited to themes such as love or partying.<ref name="rollingstone" /><ref>[http://archivo.losandes.com.ar/notas/2001/8/5/sociedad-266675.asp "El juicio del medio pelo", Los Andes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402153931/http://archivo.losandes.com.ar/notas/2001/8/5/sociedad-266675.asp |date=2015-04-02 }}</ref> It was in this situation that in 1999 the first cumbia villera band was born in the depths of ''Villa La Esperanza'' (''«Villa The Hope»''), a slum in [[San Fernando, Buenos Aires]] (north side of the Buenos Aires metropolitan area).<ref name="rollingstone" /><ref>[http://edant.clarin.com/suplementos/zona/2001/02/11/z-00315.htm "Canciones entre La Horqueta y La Cava", Clarín]</ref> [[Pablo Lescano]], then [[keytar]]ist from one of these cumbia bands, named [[Amar Azul]] (''«To Love Blue»'', but a play on words with ''"mar azul"'', ''blue sea''), started to pen new songs with more aggressive lyrics but his band rejected them, so he started saving from the royalties of the songs he penned for Amar Azul to buy instruments and equipment for producing an independent record, and created a new group with a different aesthetic, different lyrics and a different sound, [[Flor de Piedra]] (''«Stone Flower»'', a name that also has a double-entendre, meaning roughly ''«hell of a [[Crack cocaine|rock]]»'').<ref name="rollingstone" /> However, Pablo Lescano decided not to play any instrument in the band because he stayed in Amar Azul, and he just limited himself to songwriting, composing and managing. Flor de Piedra released the first cumbia villera's album (''"La Vanda Más Loca"'', ''«The Craziest Vand»'') by sending the [[Audio mastering|master]] to a ''pirate'' broadcaster due to lack of interest in major record companies, and when the song used as the promotional single and first cumbia villera song ''"Vos Sos Un Botón"'' (''«You're A Snitch»'') started to dominate the airwaves, the [[Leader Music]] label finally was interested in the band.<ref name="rollingstone" />
The records began to get heavy airplay, and soon the poor, the marginalized and the unemployed identified themselves with the new musical genre,<ref name="rollingstone" /><ref name="ventana" /> and cumbia villera spread out to other large urban settlements, eventually rising to popularity in all Argentina.<ref name="rollingstone" /><ref>[http://archivo.losandes.com.ar/notas/2001/8/5/sociedad-19057.asp "Qué hay detrás de la cumbia villera", Los Andes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402103730/http://archivo.losandes.com.ar/notas/2001/8/5/sociedad-19057.asp |date=2015-04-02 }}</ref> By 2000 there were dozens of cumbia villera bands starting, playing and recording their albums,<ref name="rollingstone" /> one of these bands was in fact the second created by Pablo Lescano (this time definitely with the role of singer and keytarist), [[Damas Gratis]] (''«Ladies Night»'' but also ''«Ladies For Free»''), which he created after a motorbike accident that cost him his place in Amar Azul.<ref name="rollingstone" /> New bands also went beyond the original foundations of Flor de Piedra and started to explore new sounds and themes, borrowing elements from [[rock music|rock]] ([[Los Gedes]], ''«The Annoying»'') or [[classical music|classical]] ([[Mala Fama]], ''«Bad Reputation»''), and making the lyrics more socially conscious ([[Guachín]], ''«Homie»'') or radically aggressive ([[Pibes Chorros]], ''«Robber Boys»''). The crisis that exploded in 2001 in Argentina strongly boosted cumbia villera's popularity and symbolized it for the posterity as an icon of an era in the history of Argentina.<ref name="rollingstone" /><ref name="ventana" /><ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/435096-contra-la-pared "Contra la pared", La Nación]</ref> It was at this point that some of the finest albums in the history of cumbia villera were released, like ''"100% Villero"'' from [[Yerba Brava]] (2001) and ''"Sólo Le Pido A Dios"'' from [[Pibes Chorros]] (2002). The genre and its repercussions were widely discussed in the [[mainstream]] media,<ref name="rollingstone" /><ref>[http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2004/01/28/o-02301.htm "Códigos de la cumbia villera", Clarín]</ref><ref>[http://periodicotribuna.com.ar/2260-cumbia-villera-fenomeno-popular.html "CUMBIA VILLERA ¿FENÓMENO POPULAR? MÚSICA MADE IN LA VILLA", Periódico Tribuna]</ref> with debates in major newspapers, magazines, TV shows, and radio shows, and the phenomenon even reached the [[television]] with ''"[[Tumberos]]"'' (2002) and the [[Film|cinema]] with ''"[[El bonaerense]]"'' (2002) and ''"[[El polaquito]]"'' (2003). Cumbia villera bands even started touring in neighbouring countries, North America and Europe, spreading the genre beyond the boundaries. This ''Argentine invasion'' greatly influenced the peoples from the Latin American countries were the bands toured, and soon there were cumbia villera bands formed in countries like [[Uruguay]] ([[La Clave]]), [[Paraguay]] ([[Los Rebeldes]]), [[Bolivia]] ([[Diego Soria]]), [[Chile]] ([[Buena Huacho]]), and [[Mexico]] ([[Cumbia Zero]]), contributing musically to the genre by using the different styles and influences from all the music genres of those nations, and contributing lyrically by using the vocabulary and [[slang]] used in the everyday life in their respective countries.
But trends in Argentine cumbia started to change by 2003, owing to the election of Argentine president [[Néstor Kirchner]] and the subsequent improvement in the nation's economy, some new measures in the Argentine music industry that affected the original cumbia villera's theme like pressure from the managers of the bands to quit singing controversial lyrics and censorship from broadcasters and the [[COMFER]] that forbade cumbia villera, though at what extent the censorship diminished cumbia villera's predominance or, on the contrary, further invigorated the musical genre, is discussed.<ref name="ventana" /><ref name="ladinamo">[http://www.ladinamo.org/ldnm/articulo.php?numero=29&id=738 "Cumbia villera para los pibes", La Dinamo]</ref><ref>[http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/dialogos/21-197149-2012-06-25.html “La cumbia nos dice mucho de la realidad social”, Página 12]</ref> The advocacy in the ''villas'' of [[christian]] groups (both [[catholic]] and [[evangelical]]) also contributed.<ref>[http://www.marthabardaro.com/prologos/Cuando%20me%20muera%20quiero%20que%20me%20toquen%20cumbia.pdf "Cuando me muera quiero que me toquen cumbia", Martha Bardaro.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304025230/http://www.marthabardaro.com/prologos/Cuando%20me%20muera%20quiero%20que%20me%20toquen%20cumbia.pdf |date=2016-03-04 }}</ref> Other causes include changes in cumbia villera's bands like breakups ([[Guachín]]), switching singers and/or other members ([[Yerba Brava]]) and downfalls in drugs or other addictions ([[Damas Gratis]]), and the rise of new cumbia bands that differed in both sound and lyrics and even aesthetics like [[La Base]] and [[El Original]] that, for the most part, avoided controversial lyrics and instead sang about love, and named their style as ''"cumbia base"'' or other monikers to avoid the implicancies of being labeled as cumbia villera and subsequently being forbidden to play in venues or receive promotion, due to the censorship of [[COMFER]].
Through the decade of the 2000s, cumbia villera continued to have a stronghold in the worker and poor communities all over Latin America, with even new bands being formed every year all over Latin America and continuing with the evolution of the genre, along with the usual constant tours around the Americas by the most representative bands like [[Damas Gratis]] and [[Pibes Chorros]]. As late as 2007, 30% of total sales in the Argentine music industry were still from cumbia villera records.<ref name="ladinamo" /> But its predominance and influence in Latin America was somewhat decreased with the rise of [[reggaeton]] that started in the mid 2000s, and [[bachata (music)|bachata]] and ''cumbia [[Wachiturros|wachiturra]]'' in the 2010s.<ref>[http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-12623048 "La cumbia se reinventa en Argentina con enfoque social", El Tiempo (Colombia)]</ref> However, other authors have different opinions, like Pablo Semán, an Argentine sociologist, anthropologist, investigator in the [[CONICET]] and professor in the ''Instituto de Altos Estudios Sociales'' and the ''Escuela de Humanidades'' of the [[Universidad Nacional de San Martín]], who also studied the phenomenon of rock ''[[rolinga]]'' and the decadence in Argentine culture in the '90s; Pablo Semán argues that cumbia villera is at last being vindicated in the decade of 2010s in circles of culture, philosophy and thought like universities and government secretaries as a genuine representative of speech by the forgotten peoples.<ref name="ventana" /> The rising promotion in the 2010s of cumbia villera bands by [[mainstream]] rock and pop publications like the [[Rolling Stone]] of Argentina magazine, the organization of gigs and concerts of cumbia villera in venues were [[mainstream]] rock and pop bands use to play, outside the ''circuito de bailantas tropicales'' (the conglomerate of the tropical and cumbia discothèques), and lastly, the close collaboration and financial production of cumbia villera bands by [[mainstream]] musicians like [[Andrés Calamaro]], [[Vicentico]] and [[Fidel Nadal]], is also a phenomenon of the 2010s decade seen as a sign of good health in the genre.<ref name="amarga" /><ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com.ar/1335733 "Damas Gratis cierra el año", Rolling Stone Argentina]</ref> Nevertheless, cumbia villera remains in the memory of the collective imaginary as the most aggressive, the most defiant and the most socially conscious style of cumbia ever made, and one of the last genres made with true social commitment in the music in recent times.<ref name="rollingstone" /><ref name="ventana" /><ref>[http://www.naya.org.ar/congreso2002/ponencias/fabian_flores_adrian_outeda.htm "100% negro cumbiero. Una aproximación al proceso de construcción de las identidades entre los jóvenes urbano marginales." Lic. Fabián C. Flores, Lic. Adrián W. Outeda - Universidad Nacional de Luján, Argentina.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402124738/http://www.naya.org.ar/congreso2002/ponencias/fabian_flores_adrian_outeda.htm |date=2015-04-02 }}</ref>
==Circumstances== Ever since the 1930s there has been a strong [[human migration|migration]] from the [[Provinces of Argentina|provinces]] (as well as from neighboring countries like [[Peru]], [[Paraguay]], and [[Bolivia]]) to the [[Greater Buenos Aires]] area where factory jobs beckoned. Migrants brought along their culture; the musical mix and the dynamic sounds of big-city life eventually gave birth to new styles. Notably, [[chamamé]] from [[Corrientes Province|Corrientes]] was cross-pollinated with [[Andes|Andean]] music and [[cuarteto]] from [[Córdoba, Argentina|Córdoba province]]. Peruvian cumbia bands such as [[Los Mirlos]] were much in demand in the Buenos Aires suburbs. During the 1970s and 1980s, ''tropical'' was used as a catch-all term for this hybrid.
In the 1990s, commercial interests started promoting local cumbia numbers such as [[Amar Azul]] and [[Ráfaga]] with a more sophisticated image and an emphasis on attracting wider audiences. Traditional cumbia lovers looked for "authentic" acts, and many bands obliged by settling on a square cumbia beat, and writing lyrics that delved ever deeper into themes of [[crime]] and [[drug abuse]]. A pioneering act was ''[[Los Pibes Chorros]]'' ("The Thieving Kids"). Other bands in this vein are ''[[Yerba Brava]]'' ("Tough Weed", a play on words referring both to [[yerba mate]] and [[marijuana]]) and ''[[Damas Gratis]]'' ("Ladies' Night", literally "Ladies for Free"), widely acknowledged as the genre's leading act, that was started by Amar Azul's former keyboardist [[Pablo Lescano]] after a serious car accident made him reconsider the message he wanted to convey through music.
The [[poverty|pauperization]] of vast segments of the population due to the [[Argentine economic crisis|economic slowdown]] that started in 1998 enlarged the social substrate that sustained the genre. The term ''cumbia villera'' took hold in the media, and many bands were propelled into fame when emerging [[football (soccer)|football]] stars from the shantytowns, such as [[Carlos Tevez]], proclaimed their allegiance. When his schedule allows, Tevez is lead singer for [[Piola Vago]] (loose translation: "savvy bum").
Cumbia villera may be musically related to other local cumbia scenes such as [[Mexico|Mexican]] cumbia sonidera and [[Peruvian cumbia|chicha]] from [[Peru]]. [[Reggaeton]] and [[hip-hop]] are less frequent influences.
==Present outlook== Some radio and TV shows had incorporated ''cumbia villera'' into their offerings, notably on weekend ''omnibus'' variety shows, where music runs the gamut from [[folklore]] to ''tropical''. The more provocative lyrics were seldom broadcast. Some of the bands gained audiences outside of Argentina, notably in [[Uruguay]] and [[Chile]]. Due to pressure from broadcasters and (allegedly) influence from [[Evangelicalism|Evangelical]] preachers active in the shantytowns, bands with less aggressive lyrics have enjoyed some success.
==Parallels== Whilst traditional cumbia dancing bands often use a full [[brass instrument|brass]] section, cumbia villera recordings are often made at the lowest possible expense. As this usually entails the use of [[synthesizer]]s, Argentine cumbia can be described, like [[Algeria]]n [[raï]], Romanian [[manele]] or Brazilian [[baile funk]], as a "low-fidelity, high-tech" genre.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://archive.is/20130117034735/http://www.arte-tv.com/de/kunst-musik/tracks/Sendung_20vom_2021._20Februar_202003/391712,CmC=391720.html Backstage (German)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050906172906/http://www.arte-tv.com/fr/art-musique/tracks/Emission_20du_2021_20f_C3_A9vrier_202003/391712%2CCmC%3D391720.html Backstage (French)] * [http://elortiba.galeon.com/cumbiavi.html Sociological analysis (Spanish)] * http://www.cumbiadenegros.net/
{{Cumbia}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Dritan Hoxha | image = | alt = | caption = Dritan Hoxha in 2007 | birth_name = Dritan Hoxha | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1968|09|20}} | birth_place = [[Kukes]], [[Albania]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2008|05|23|1968|10|16}} | death_place = [[Tirana]], [[Albania]] | othername = | occupation = Albanian businessman
Founder of [[Top Channel]] and [[DigitAlb]] | years_active = 1993-2008 | spouse = Vjollca Hoxha | domesticpartner = | website = }} '''Dritan Hoxha''' (20 September 1968 – 23 May 2008) was an [[Albania]]n businessman. He was the founder of [[Top Channel|Top Media]], Albania's largest media company. Hoxha, who started his business career as a [[coffee]] importer with the Lori Caffe, founded Top Media in 1998. Firstly he founded the biggest Albanian radio station "Top Albania Radio". Along with Top Media he also founded the digital platform "[[Digitalb|DigitAlb]]" and the newspaper "Shqip". In 2008 [[Digitalb|DigitAlb]] became the first European Platform with 6 [[high-definition video|High Definition]] Channels and the second in world. This was a big achievement for [[Albania]]. He clashed with Prime Minister [[Sali Berisha]] over satellite broadcasting rights. Berisha fined Hoxha's group 13 million euros but they later reached a compromise.[http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-33739820080523 Albanian media magnate dies in car crash] ''Reuters'' During this time he also faced accusations of [[tax evasion]] which he denied. ==Death== Hoxha died on the morning of 23 May 2008 at about 02:00 in [[Tirana]] when he crashed his [[Ferrari 599]] into a tree near Top Media Headquarters. [http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/main/news/10421/ Albanian Media Mogul Dies in Road Accident] ''BalkanInsight'' He died on the way to [[Tirana Military Hospital]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hoxha, Dritan}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:2008 deaths]] [[Category:Road incident deaths in Albania]] [[Category:Albanian businesspeople]] [[Category:Albanian mass media owners]] [[Category:Telecommunications in Albania]] [[Category:Television in Albania]] [[Category:People from Kukës]] {{Albania-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox television | show_name = Drive In | image = Drive In (variety show).jpg | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = [[Variety show|Variety]]
[[Sketch Comedy]] | presenter = [[Gianfranco D'Angelo]]
[[Ezio Greggio]]
[[Enrico Beruschi]] | announcer = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | country = Italy | language = | num_seasons = 6 | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | producer = | executive_producer = | location = | camera = | runtime = | network = [[Italia 1]] | picture_format = [[Color television|Color]] | audio_format = | first_aired = October 4, 1983 | last_aired = April 17, 1988 }} '''''Drive In''''' is an Italian television variety show, broadcast by [[Italia 1]] between 1983 and 1988. It was referred as the most innovative and popular Italian television show of the 1980s.Aldo Grasso – Massimo Scaglioni, ''Enciclopedia della Televisione'', Garzanti, Milano, 1996 – 2003, p.215 == History == Created by [[Antonio Ricci (producer)|Antonio Ricci]], the show revolutioned Italian TV conventions and languages, proposing a zany, sharp and fast humor, partly imported from the model of the ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''. It also proposed a new, different image of the women, more sensual and transgressive. In reason of its high audience ratings, it has a key role in the success of [[Silvio Berlusconi]]'s [[Fininvest]] (now [[Mediaset]]).{{cite book|last=Sandra Puccini|title=Nude e crudi: femminile e maschile nell'Italia di oggi|publisher=Donzelli Editore, 2009|pages=3–7}} The show launched the careers of several comedians (such as [[Ezio Greggio]], [[Giorgio Faletti]], [[Francesco Salvi]]) as well as of a number of showgirls (including [[Tinì Cansino]] and [[Lory Del Santo]]). It generated a series of imitation programs, several of them also created by the same Antonio Ricci.{{cite book|last=Aldo Grasso|title=Radio e televisione: teorie, analisi, storie, esercizi|publisher=Vita e Pensiero, 2000|page=182}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Joseph Baroni. ''Dizionario della Televisione''. Raffaello Cortina Editore, pp. 139–142. {{ISBN|88-7078-972-1}}. [[Category:Italian television shows]] [[Category:Variety television series]] {{Italy-tv-prog-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox video game | title = Futuridium EP Deluxe | image = Futuridium EP Deluxe coverart.png | developer = MixedBag | publisher = MixedBag
[[Playism]] | engine = [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] | platforms = [[PlayStation 4]]
[[PlayStation Vita]]
[[Wii U]]
[[New Nintendo 3DS]]
[[iOS]]
[[Microsoft Windows]]
[[Mac OS X]]
[[Linux]] | released = '''PlayStation 4, PlayStation Vita'''{{vgrelease|NA|September 30, 2014|EU|October 1, 2014|AU|October 1, 2014}}'''iOS'''{{vgrelease|NA|July 18, 2016}}'''Microsoft Windows'''{{vgrelease|NA|July 15, 2016}}'''Wii U'''{{vgrelease|NA|May 26, 2016}}'''New Nintendo 3DS'''{{vgrelease|NA|September 8, 2016|EU|September 15, 2016}} | genre = [[Shoot'em up]] | series = | composer = Omar Ferrero
Luca Gasperoni | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] }} '''''Futuridium EP Deluxe''''' is an [[Indie game|indie]] [[shoot'em up]] [[video game]] developed by Italian developer MixedBag{{cite web|url=http://press.mixedbag.it/index.php|title=MixedBag Srl|work=press.mixedbag.it|accessdate=1 October 2014}} for the [[PlayStation 4]], [[PlayStation Vita]], [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Mac OS X|OS X]] and [[Linux]]. It was released in North America on September 30, 2014{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2014/09/25/futuridium-ep-deluxe-races-to-ps4-ps-vita-tuesday/|title=Futuridium EP Deluxe Races to PS4, PS Vita Tuesday|last=Fanelli|first=Mauro|work=blog.us.playstation.com|date=25 September 2014|accessdate=1 October 2014}} and on October 1, 2014 in Europe.{{cite web|url=http://blog.eu.playstation.com/2014/09/25/futuridium-ep-deluxe-blasts-onto-ps4-ps-vita-next-week/|title=Futuridium EP Deluxe blasts onto PS4 & PS Vita next week|last=Fanelli|first=Mauro|work=blog.eu.playstation.com|date=25 September 2014|accessdate=1 October 2014}} The design of the game was influenced by the Commodore 64 title ''[[Uridium]]'' and the ''[[Star Fox (series)|Star Fox]]'' series.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-02-18-psychedelic-space-shooter-futuridium-headed-to-playstation-vita|title=Psychedelic space shooter Futuridium headed to PlayStation Vita|last=Phillips|first=Tom|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=18 February 2014|accessdate=17 January 2015}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | GR = 73% (PSVITA){{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/vita/849815-futuridium-ep-deluxe/index.html|title=Futuridium EP Deluxe for PlayStation Vita - GameRankings|work=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=26 May 2017}}
70% (PS4){{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ps4/849814-futuridium-ep-deluxe/index.html|title=Futuridium EP Deluxe for PlayStation 4 - GameRankings|work=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=27 November 2014}}
66% (iOS){{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/iphone/723577-futuridium-ep/index.html|title=Futuridium EP Deluxe for iOS - GameRankings|work=[[GameRankings]]|accessdate=17 January 2015}} | MC = 73/100 (PS4){{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-4/futuridium-ep-deluxe|title=Futuridium EP Deluxe for PlayStation 4 Reviews|work=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=26 May 2017}}
70/100 (iOS){{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/ios/futuridium-ep|title=Futuridium EP Deluxe for iPhone/iPad Reviews|work=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=17 January 2015}}
65/100 (PSVITA){{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-vita/futuridium-ep-deluxe|title=Futuridium EP Deluxe for PlayStation Vita Reviews|work=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=27 November 2014}} | IGN = 8/10{{cite web|url=http://it.ign.com/indiegram/86231/review/indiegram-6?p=2|title=Indiegram #6|last=Baldo|first=Di Lorenzo|work=it.ign.com|language=Italian|date=10 October 2014|accessdate=14 October 2014}} | rev1 = ''Nintendo Life'' | rev1Score = 7/10http://www.nintendolife.com/games/wiiu-eshop/futuridium_ep_deluxe }} ''Futuridium EP Deluxe'' was received mixed to positive reviews upon release. The PlayStation Vita version holds a 75% rating on [[review aggregator]] [[GameRankings]], while the PlayStation 4 version has a 70% rating. On [[Metacritic]], the PlayStation 4 and Vita versions hold scores of 74/100 and 65/100 respectively. [[IGN]] gave both versions an 8/10. ==Release== On March 3, 2016, it was announced that ''Futuridium EP Deluxe'' would be releasing on both the New Nintendo 3DS and Wii U platforms within the year.{{cite web|url=http://crashlanded.co.uk/limited-run-games-futuridium-ep-deluxe.php|title=Futuridium EP Deluxe announced for Limited Run Games and Nintendo platforms|last=Robinson|first=Dave|date=4 March 2016|accessdate=5 March 2016}} On March 4, 2016, developer MixedBag{{cite web|url=http://press.mixedbag.it/index.php|title=MixedBag Srl|work=press.mixedbag.it|accessdate=5 March 2016}} revealed that ''Futuridium EP Deluxe'' would receive a limited physical release of just 4,000 copies through ''Limited Run Games'' between both the PlayStation 4 and PlayStation Vita. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://press.mixedbag.it/sheet.php?p=futuridium_eP_deluxe Press kit] [[Category:2014 video games]] [[Category:iOS games]] [[Category:Indie video games]] [[Category:Linux games]] [[Category:MacOS games]] [[Category:New Nintendo 3DS games]] [[Category:Nintendo 3DS eShop games]] [[Category:PlayStation 4 games]] [[Category:PlayStation Vita games]] [[Category:PlayStation Network games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Italy]] [[Category:Shooter video games]] [[Category:Unity (game engine) games]] [[Category:Wii U eShop games]] [[Category:Windows games]] {{shmup-videogame-stub}}

{{about|the nickname of the Canadian film industry|the film|Hollywood North (film)|other uses|Hollywood (disambiguation)}} [[Image:Hollywood North Movie.jpg|thumb|right|The 2004 Canadian film ''[[Hollywood North (film)|Hollywood North]]'', a film about two [[Toronto]]-based film producers and their struggles in the late-1970s]] '''Hollywood North''' is a [[colloquialism]] used to describe [[film production]] industries and/or film locations north of its namesake, [[Hollywood]], [[California]]. The term has been applied principally to the [[Cinema of Canada|film industry in Canada]], specifically [[Toronto]] and [[Vancouver]]. The level of Canadian production has increased since the ratification of the [[Canada–United States Free Trade Agreement]] in 1988.
==Use of the term== The term "Hollywood North" has been used to describe aspects of Vancouver film and television production since the late 1970s,<ref name="news.google.com">'Montreal Gazette''.{{cite web |url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yv0hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=a6QFAAAAIBAJ&dq=hollywood-north%20canada&pg=4439%2C331425|title= Movie Making turns Toronto into a Mecca for star gazers''|accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref><ref>'The Windsor Star''.{{cite web |url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jVI_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=M1IMAAAAIBAJ&dq=hollywood-north%20canada&pg=1062%2C3649091|title= Hollywood North Growing Up...Finally''|accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Judy|last=Steed|title=Pay Television|website=The Globe and Mail|date=8 September 1981|page= 7}}</ref> even appearing in the titles of books (i.e. ''Hollywood North: The Feature Film Industry in British Columbia''<ref name="gasher">{{cite book| last = Gasher | first = Mike | title = Hollywood North: The Feature Film Industry in British Columbia | publisher = University of British Columbia Press | year = 2002 | location = Vancouver | isbn = 0-7748-0967-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.siegelproductions.ca/filmfanatics/hollywood.htm|title=Hollywood|publisher=Lois Siegel|accessdate=2006-12-24}}</ref>) and films (''[[Hollywood North (film)|Hollywood North]]''). The title has been claimed for both [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]],<ref name="VFSH">{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouverfilmstudios.com/history.html |title=History of Vancouver Film Studios |publisher=Vancouver Film Studios |accessdate=2007-02-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070108091043/http://www.vancouverfilmstudios.com/history.html |archivedate=2007-01-08 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://search.cbc.ca/search?ie=&site=CBC&output=xml_no_dtd&client=CBC&lr=&getfields=description&proxystylesheet=CBC&oe=&searchWeb=cbc&q=Hollywood+North|title=CBC: Searched for 'Hollywood North'|publisher=CBC News|accessdate=2007-01-02}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.ca/search?hl=en&q=%22Hollywood+North+Vancouver%22&btnG=Google+Search&meta=|title=Hollywood North Vancouver|publisher=Google Inc.|accessdate=2007-01-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/1999/07/12/bcfilm990712.html|title='Hollywood North' to grow again|publisher=CBC News|date= November 10, 2000|accessdate=2007-01-02}}</ref> and [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]]<ref name="Accessing City Hall">{{cite web|url=http://wx.toronto.ca/inter/it/newsrel.nsf/0/a196b48a551afa4285256df600461208?OpenDocument|title=New numbers confirm Toronto's rank as Hollywood North|publisher=City of Toronto|accessdate=2007-01-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/story/2004/03/09/quickhits090304.html|title=SARS costs for 'Hollywood North' and more|date=March 9, 2004|publisher=CBC News|accessdate=2007-01-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080330145114/http://www.torontoisms.com/guide/crime.htm|archivedate=March 30, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.ca/search?hl=en&safe=off&q=%22Hollywood+North+Toronto%22&btnG=Search&meta=|title=Hollywood North Toronto|publisher=Google Inc.|accessdate=2007-01-01}}</ref>
=== Toronto === {{See also|Category:Films shot in Toronto|Category:Television series produced in Toronto|List of filming locations in Toronto}} [[Image:2002 Toronto International Film Festival poster.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Official poster of the 2002 [[Toronto International Film Festival]]]] One of the earliest Hollywood television series to shoot in Toronto was the 1957 production ''[[Hawkeye and the Last of the Mohicans]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.members.tripod.com/~JohnHart/starhawk.htm|title=Steve Jensen's ''Toronto Star'' archives for ''Hawkeye and the Last of the Mohicans'' (1956-1957)|accessdate=2007-09-18}}</ref> The city has been associated with the nickname 'Hollywood North' since the late 1970s, due to its role as a production centre for both domestic and international film projects.<ref>'Sarasota Herald-Tribune''.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DkUfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mmcEAAAAIBAJ&dq=toronto%20hollywood%20north&pg=4458%2C1049685|title=Toronto Now Called Hollywood of North ''|accessdate=10 June 2011}}''</ref><ref>'Youngstown Vindicator''.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9PJIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=54IMAAAAIBAJ&dq=hollywood-north%20toronto&pg=1125%2C4634454|title=Tax Credit Plan Helps Toronto Gain Stature As Hollywood of the North''|accessdate=10 June 2011}}''</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PI&s_site=philly&p_multi=PI&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB2996E78DA21BB&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Toronto has Earned a New Title|date=May 26, 1985|website=The Philadelphia Inquirer|accessdate=2007-02-13}}</ref> In 1979 Toronto mayor [[John Sewell]] announced that Canada had become the third largest movie production centre after Los Angeles and New York.<ref name="news.google.com" />
The actors and crew members central database is operated by [https://www.torontofilmindustry.com The Toronto Film Industry Arts & Entertainment Foundation]
In 2002 the year Toronto's Film and Television industry accounted for $1.16 billion towards the city's economy, former Toronto Mayor [[Mel Lastman]] proclaimed "Toronto is Hollywood North".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://wx.toronto.ca/inter/it/newsrel.nsf/0/a196b48a551afa4285256df600461208?OpenDocument|title=New numbers confirm Toronto's rank as Hollywood North|date=February 6, 2001|publisher=Access Toronto|accessdate=2002-02-06}}</ref> In 2003 the Toronto Ontario Film Office was established in Los Angeles to promote the benefits of filming in the city of Toronto and the province of Ontario.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.omdc.on.ca/Page3682.aspx|title=The Toronto Ontario Film Office in Los Angeles|date=2011-06-12|publisher=OMDC}}</ref> With the TOFO [[Ontario]] is the only Canadian province to have an office in Hollywood.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediacom.keio.ac.jp/publication/pdf2006/review28/02_Minoru%20SUGAYA.pdf|title=The Development of Film Policy in Canada and Japan-Pg.11|publisher=Keio Communications|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-01-15}}</ref> The province of Ontario had 230 film projects with $946 million in production spending in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.omdc.on.ca/Page6010.aspx|title=Ontario Film and Television Production 2008-2010 sorted by format|date=2011-06-10|publisher=OMDC}}</ref>
Ontario ranks as the largest film and television production centre in Canada, and third overall in [[North America]] behind [[California]] and [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ontario.ca/en/initiatives/progressreport2012/ONT05_040343.html|title=Progress Report 2012: Economy|date=2012-086-31|publisher=Government of Ontario|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120823052253/http://www.ontario.ca/en/initiatives/progressreport2012/ONT05_040343.html|archivedate=August 23, 2012}}</ref> A decline in BC's domestic production and an increase of $300 million or 31% over the previous year, allowed Ontario to surpass British Columbia for the largest production centre in Canada in 2011. The province recorded $1.26 billion in production activity in 2011, its largest year ever.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/917477/ontario-s-film-television-production-records-best-year-ever|title=Ontario's film & television production records best year ever|date=2012-08-31|publisher=Canada Newswire}}</ref> By 2017, Toronto itself grew to $2 billion.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Wong |first1=Tony |title=How Toronto’s film and TV production has surged past $2 billion |url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/television/2017/06/02/how-torontos-film-and-tv-production-has-surged-past-2-billion.html |accessdate=18 September 2018 |work=[[Toronto Star]] |date=2 June 2017}}</ref>
Toronto ranks second as an exporter of television programming in North America<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toronto.ca/toronto_facts/art_culture.htm|title=Toronto Facts|publisher=City of Toronto|accessdate=2007-01-14}}</ref> and behind only Los Angeles and New York City among North American cities in total industry production,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toronto.ca/legdocs/mmis/2012/ed/bgrd/backgroundfile-45805.pdf|title=Film and Television Industry: 2011 Year in Review|date=2012-09-01|publisher=City of Toronto}}</ref> $903.5 million were spent by production companies on 209 major production film and television projects in 2010 in Toronto.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toronto.ca/tfto/pdf/stats.pdf|title=Total Production Spending in the City of Toronto 2010|date=2011-06-11|publisher=Toronto Film and Television Office}}</ref> In 2011, the film industry contributed $1.13 billion from 244 on location film and television projects to Toronto<ref name="Film and Television in Toronto">{{cite web|url=http://www.toronto.ca/tfto/pdf/tfto_2011_stats.pdf|title=Film and Television in Toronto|date=2012-07-01|publisher=Toronto Film and Television Office}}</ref> the largest figure since the year 2002, this increase in revenue over the past years was attributed to a film tax credit offered by the provincial government in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://toronto.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20120326/good-year-for-toronto-film-profits-2011-120326/20120326/?hub=TorontoNewHome|title=Toronto film industry posts banner year|date=2012-03-26|publisher=CTV News}}</ref> A 47% increase in Hollywood productions in 2011 over 2010 was mostly attributed to this tax credit among others.<ref name="Film and Television in Toronto" /><ref name="Business In Vancouver" /> In 2012 on location film and television production increased again to $1.2 billion generated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cartt.ca/news/15440/Radio-Television/Toronto-film-TV-industry-production-in-2012-at-highest-levels-since-2002.html|title=Toronto film, TV industry productions in 2012 at highest levels since 2002|date=2013-04-30|publisher=Cartt.ca|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130628044738/http://www.cartt.ca/news/15440/Radio-Television/Toronto-film-TV-industry-production-in-2012-at-highest-levels-since-2002.html|archivedate=2013-06-28|df=}}</ref>
Toronto is the home base for [[Alliance Atlantis]], the largest distribution company in Canada,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://biz.yahoo.com/ic/47/47787.html|title=Alliance Atlantis Communications Inc. Company Profile|publisher=Yahoo.com|accessdate=2007-02-10}}</ref> and the 12th largest film and TV distribution company in the world,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canadiangeographic.ca/worldmap/cg/news.asp|title=The News from Home|date=2011-06-11|publisher=Canadian Geographic|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070203024637/http://www.canadiangeographic.ca/worldmap/cg/news.asp|archivedate=2007-02-03|df=}}</ref> which distributes films and television across all of North America and parts of [[Europe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.busadm.mu.edu/aim/documents/AIM_Advisory_Board_Meeting_Sept_21_2006.pdf|title=Marquette University (AIM) Program|publisher=Marquette university|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-02-10}}</ref> Toronto is also the headquarters of [[Nelvana]], the largest animation company in Canada and one of the largest animation/children's entertainment studios in the world.
[[Pinewood Toronto Studios]] located in [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], Canada is Canada's largest film and television production complex, with more than {{convert|250,000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of production space. It contains the largest purpose-built sound stage in North America,<ref name="Pinewood Toronto Studios">{{cite web|url=http://www.pinewoodtorontostudios.com/|title=Pinewood Toronto Studios|accessdate=2011-06-10}}</ref> capable of accommodating large blockbuster movies.<ref name="FILMPORTB">{{cite web|url=http://www.filmport.ca/|title=Official site: FILMPORT|accessdate=2008-02-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226203230/http://www.filmport.ca/|archivedate=2008-02-26|df=}}</ref><ref name="FILMPORTC">{{cite web|url=http://torontoist.com/2007/07/filmport.php|title=Torontoist: "Curtain Rising On New Film Megastudio."|accessdate=2008-02-04}}</ref><ref name="FILMPORTJ">{{cite web|url=http://www.toronto.ca/tobusiness/2007-august.htm#story6|title=Toronto Economic Development Corporation: "FILMPORT to include largest sound-stage in North America."|accessdate=2008-02-04}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Some have credited the completion of Pinewood Studios along with provincial tax credits as being responsible for the late 2000s/early 2010s surge in in-province Hollywood productions. Due to its ability to handle film productions on a scale not previously possible.<ref name="Business In Vancouver" />
The Toronto Film and Television Office reported that in 2005 some 200 productions were completed in Toronto: 39 features, and 44 movies made for television, 84 television series, 11 television specials, and 22 MOW's (movies of the week).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toronto.ca/tfto/pdf/stats_2000_to_2005.pdf|title=TFTO Statistical Chart|publisher=City of Toronto|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-01-14}}</ref> The Toronto Film and Television Office issued 4,154 location filming permits for 1,258 projects totalling 7,319 days of shooting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toronto.ca/tfto/stats.htm|title=A snapshot: film, television, commercial and music video production in Toronto|publisher=City of Toronto|accessdate=2007-01-15}}</ref> Toronto's domestic production industry benefits greatly financially from large [[International co-production|treaty coproductions]] with international partners.<ref name="Straight.com" />
As with Vancouver, government tax incentives at both the provincial and federal level promote Toronto as a destination for many US film productions. The city is often used as a stand in for [[New York City]] and [[Chicago]] in film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toronto.ca/tfto/newy.htm|title=Productions shot in Toronto representing New York|date=2011-06-11|publisher=Toronto Film and Television Office}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/film/story/2010/03/25/atom-egoyan-chloe.html|title=Chloe stars steamy Toronto as itself|date=2011-06-11|publisher=CBC}}</ref>
In addition to being a productions centre, Toronto is the home to the [[Toronto International Film Festival]], which is considered by many in the film industry to be second only to [[Cannes Film Festival|Cannes]] in terms of influence<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/film/4513373.stm|title=Film Festival Guide|last=Tobias|first=Scott|date=May 2005|publisher=BBC NEWS|accessdate=2007-02-08}}</ref> or in instances actually rivaling it.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/features/2007/09/toronto200709|title=Toronto Rising|last=Ortved|first=John|date=May 2007|publisher=Vanity Fair|accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/Special/FilmFest/article/253723|title=Toronto's Film Festival Rival Cannes|last=Kopune|first=Francine|date=September 2007|website=Toronto Star|accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref> It attracts numerous high-profile actors and film makers from around the globe to premiere their Films in Toronto and is generally considered the tip-off point to which the [[Academy Award|Oscar]] races begin.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20040912/FILMFESTIVALS03/409120303|title=Toronto fires starter's gun for Oscar race|publisher=Roger Ebert.com|accessdate=2007-02-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://theenvelope.latimes.com/awards/oscars/env-oneiltorontoroundup-18sep18,0,5735401.story?coll=env-home-headlines&track=mostviewed-storylevel|title=Top Oscar rivals emerge from Toronto|last=O'Neil|first=Tom|date=September 18, 2006|publisher=LA Times|accessdate=2007-02-09}}</ref>
Toronto is home to [[Canada's Walk of Fame]], similar in appearance to the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]], honouring notable Canadians.
Toronto is the headquarters to the majority of Canada's national media outlets including: [[CBC Television]], [[CTV Television Network|CTV]], [[Global Television Network]], [[MuchMusic]], [[YTV (TV channel)|YTV]], and entertainment programs [[ETalk]] and ''[[Entertainment Tonight Canada|Entertainment Tonight]]''. The city is the traditional host for the [[Gemini Awards]], honouring the Canadian television industry.
===Vancouver=== {{See also|Category:Films shot in Vancouver|Category:Television series produced in Vancouver|List of filming locations in the Vancouver area}} Vancouver has been used as a filmmaking location for over a century, beginning with ''The Cowpuncher's Glove'' and ''The Ship's Husband'', both shot in 1910 by the [[Edison Studios|Edison Manufacturing Company]].<ref>Ken MacIntyre. ''Reel Vancouver.'' Vancouver: Whitecap Books, 1996. p. 133.</ref> Isolated by distance from the domestic film production communities in Toronto and Montreal,<ref>{{cite book|last=Gasher|first=Mike|title=Hollywood North: the feature film industry in British Columbia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EiQlVzWWoFMC&pg=PA67|accessdate=12 June 2011|date=2002-08-01|publisher=UBC Press|isbn=978-0-7748-0968-9|pages=67–}}</ref> it became known as "Hollywood North"<ref>Mike Gasher. ''Hollywood North: The Feature Film Industry in British Columbia.'' Vancouver: University of British Columbia Press, 2002. p. 8.</ref> for its role as a production centre for US feature films shot in British Columbia. The provincial government first established a film development office in 1977 to market the province to the Hollywood community.<ref>{{cite book|last=Gasher|first=Mike|title=Hollywood North: the feature film industry in British Columbia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EiQlVzWWoFMC&pg=PA69|accessdate=12 June 2011|date=2002-08-01|publisher=UBC Press|isbn=978-0-7748-0968-9|pages=69–}}</ref> In 2000, BC crossed the billion-dollar mark in production for the first time,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/story/2000/02/08/bc_filmtax000208.html|title=Tax scare in Hollywood North|publisher=CBC News|accessdate=2007-01-01|date=2000-02-08}}</ref> and in 2002, 75% of all Canadian foreign productions were based in British Columbia and Ontario. That same year British Columbia led the country in foreign film production receiving 44% of the Canadian total.<ref name="SCR">{{cite web|url=http://www41.statcan.ca/3955/ceb3955_003_e.htm |title=Hollywood North: The Canadian film industry |publisher=Statistics Canada |accessdate=2006-12-24 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070712074814/http://www41.statcan.ca/3955/ceb3955_003_e.htm |archivedate=2007-07-12 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
British Columbia held the ranking of third largest production centre for film and television in North America for years, after [[Los Angeles]] and [[New York City]],<ref name="Who we are">{{cite web|url=http://www.bcfilmcommission.com/about_us/industry_profile/articles44.php|title=Who we are|publisher=BC Film Commission|date=2011-06-10|accessdate=2010-06-10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605131305/http://www.bcfilmcommission.com/about_us/industry_profile/articles44.php|archivedate=2010-06-05|df=}}</ref> with over 246 motion picture projects and $1.02 billion on production spending in 2010.<ref name="Straight.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.straight.com/article-624511/vancouver/bc-drops-fourth-largest-north-american-film-production-centre|title=B.C. drops to fourth largest North American film production centre|publisher=Straight.com|date=2012-08-12|access-date=2017-08-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110021350/http://www.straight.com/article-624511/vancouver/bc-drops-fourth-largest-north-american-film-production-centre|archive-date=2012-11-10|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bcfilmcommission.com/database/rte/files/2010FinalStats%20Package.pdf|title=2010 Production Statistics|publisher=BC Film Commission|date=2011-06-10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928103753/http://www.bcfilmcommission.com/database/rte/files/2010FinalStats%20Package.pdf|archivedate=2011-09-28|df=}}</ref> However, declining domestic production in the province through 2011 and less competitive tax rates left BC ranked fourth in overall production after Ontario for a few years.<ref name="Business In Vancouver">{{cite web|url=http://www.biv.com/article/20120320/BIV0103/303209916/-1/BIV/ontario-film-industry-outperforming-bcs|title=Ontario film industry outperforming B.C.'s|publisher=Business In Vancouver|date=2012-03-20|accessdate=2012-08-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121216234343/http://www.biv.com/article/20120320/BIV0103/303209916/-1/BIV/ontario-film-industry-outperforming-bcs|archive-date=2012-12-16|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="Straight.com"/><ref name="Who we are"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/story/2012/05/16/bc-film-business-woes.html|title=B.C. film industry seeks tax break in 'bad year'|publisher=CBC|date=2012-08-12}}</ref> However, it recently, it has regained its position as the third largest production center in North America.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vancouver.ca/news-calendar/2015-a-record-year-for-television-and-film-in-vancouver.aspx|title=2015 a record year for television and film in Vancouver|publisher=City of Vancouver|date=2016-02-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://vancouversun.com/news/local-news/boom-time-for-residents-businesses-in-hollywood-north|title=Boom-time for residents, businesses in Hollywood North|publisher=Vancouver Sun|date=2016-04-08}}</ref>
North Shore Studios - formally Lionsgate Studios - and [[Vancouver Film Studios]] are among the two largest special effects stages in Canada.<ref name="VFSH" /><ref name="hwnn">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodnorthpr.com/industry.html|title=BC Film Industry|publisher=Hollywood North FilmNet|accessdate=2006-12-24}}</ref> VFS being one of the largest production facility outside of [[Los Angeles]];<ref name="VDCVFS">{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouver.com/movies/hollywood_north/vancouver_film_industry_overview/index.htm|title=Vancouver Film Industry Overview & Links|publisher=Vancouver.com|accessdate=2007-02-10}}</ref> [[Bridge Studios]], in [[Burnaby]], [[British Columbia]], has one of the largest special effects stages in North America.<ref name="hwnn" /> Mammoth Studios, a subsidiary of North Shore studios holds the largest film stages in the world,{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} their largest at {{convert|123,883|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nsstudios.ca/|title=Mammoth Studios|publisher=North Shore Studios|year=2009}}</ref>
The BC Film Commission reported that in 2005, more than 200 productions were completed in B.C.: 63 feature films, 31 television series, 37 movies-of-the-week, 15 television pilots, 5 miniseries, 20 documentaries, 16 short films and 24 animation projects.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mayor's Office Release |url=http://vancouver.ca/ctyclerk/councillors/mayor/announcements/2006/100306.htm |publisher=City of Vancouver |accessdate=2006-12-24 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> In 2006, spending on film and TV production in B.C. was $1.228 billion.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/business/story.html?id=a9ff5b13-6c29-4cd5-b30c-25be092ce384&k=88313&p=1 |title=? |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106055019/http://www.canada.com/vancouversun/news/business/story.html?id=a9ff5b13-6c29-4cd5-b30c-25be092ce384&k=88313&p=1 |archivedate=2012-11-06 |df= }}</ref> The [[Great Recession]] of the late 2000s hit the film industry financially on all levels. By March 2008, the British Columbia film industry dramatically recovered with film spending at $1.2 billion, with foreign-film production increasing 146 percent and domestic animation by 79 percent. In total, 86 foreign productions including 40 feature-length films, were completed in 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.straight.com/article-205092/bc-film-production-almost-30-percent-2008|title=B.C. film production up almost 30 percent in 2008|last=Smith|first=Charlie|date=March 9, 2009|work=Vancouver Free Press|publisher=[[The Georgia Straight]]|location=[[Vancouver]]|accessdate=2009-08-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090316021952/http://straight.com/article-205092/bc-film-production-almost-30-percent-2008|archive-date=March 16, 2009|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The city is also host to the [[Vancouver International Film Festival]] and the [[Vancouver Film and Television Forum]].
Over the last few years, many states and provinces have increased their tax incentives matching and even exceeding the ones offered in British Columbia which has made it more competitive for the province. These states include Georgia (30% based on a minimum investment of $500,000<ref>http://www.georgia.org/GeorgiaIndustries/Entertainment/AboutUs/Pages/Incentives.aspx</ref>), New Mexico (20% Refundable Tax Credit<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nmfilm.com/filming/incentives/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509163914/http://www.nmfilm.com/filming/incentives/ |archivedate=2008-05-09 |df= }}</ref>), and North Carolina (25% Refundable Tax Credit<ref>http://www.ncfilm.com/</ref>).
Vancouver is {{convert|1,725|km|mi}} from [[Hollywood]], a three-hour airplane flight<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.orbitz.com/flight-info/MX/MX-YVR-LAX.html|title=Flights to Los Angeles (LAX) from Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada (YVR) on Mexicana|publisher=Orbitz, LLC.|accessdate=2007-02-10}}</ref> or a 21-hour drive.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&source=s_d&saddr=vancouver+bc&daddr=Hollywood,+Los+Angeles,+CA,+United+States&hl=en&geocode=Faqq7wIdOW6p-CmzT6lD8XOGVDGL84Gb6paRuw%3BFZpMCAIdun3y-Cm_eVIEB7_CgDHk-r2XZ5p69g&mra=ls&sll=41.65679,-120.818655&sspn=26.559454,57.084961&ie=UTF8&ll=41.672912,-120.849609&spn=26.559454,57.084961&z=5|title=Vancouver, BC, Canada to Hollywood, Los Angeles, CA -|date=2011-06-11|work=[[Google Search]]|publisher=Google Maps|accessdate=11 June 2011}}</ref> It is also in the same [[Pacific Time Zone|time zone]] as Los Angeles. This relative proximity coupled with government subsidies is a major factor in the growth of Vancouver's production industry.<ref name="CBCBUP">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/story/1998/04/24/bcfilm980424a.html|title=B.C. tries to build up Hollywood North|date= November 13, 1998|publisher=CBC News|accessdate=2007-02-10}}</ref> Proximity reduces issues over operating hours, accessibility, travel time for principals, access to filmmaking infrastructure, and experience of crews.<ref name="CBCBUP"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/movies/next-superman-film-to-be-shot-in-vancouver-sources/article1841715/|title=Next Superman film to be shot in Vancouver|date=2010-12-17|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|accessdate=12 June 2011|location=Toronto|first=Marsha|last=Lederman}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=a9ff5b13-6c29-4cd5-b30c-25be092ce384&sponsor=|title=Foreign filmmakers flocking to B.C.: Makers of foreign television series have decided that B.C. is the place to be, regardless of where in the world it's supposed to represent|date=2007-03-27|work=[[Postmedia News]]|publisher=Vancouver Sun|accessdate=12 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110120618/http://www.canada.com/story_print.html?id=a9ff5b13-6c29-4cd5-b30c-25be092ce384&sponsor=|archivedate=10 November 2012|df=}}</ref> Another reason why foreign producers choose Vancouver to film is because of the consistent cloud cover as this weather naturally diffuses natural sunlight which makes it easier for technicians to add additional light.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}}
